channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Zika Epidemic, a Warning on Climate Change
item.description: In the coming decades, global warming is likely to increase the range and speed the life cycle of the particular mosquitoes carrying viruses like Zika.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Smoke from a brush fire in a deforested part of Brazil’s Amazon basin. The Zika virus, which is an epidemic in Brazil, is transmitted mainly by mosquitoes.

item.title: Afghan Troops Retreat Under Pressure From Taliban
item.description: The pullout in the southern Helmand Province is the latest blow to an area that had been teetering for months in the face of resurgent Taliban members.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghans fleeing because of battles between government troops and militants are checked by the police Saturday in Musa Qala.

item.title: Yoweri Museveni, Uganda’s President, Wins a Widely Criticized Election
item.description: Mr. Museveni, the country’s longtime president, cruised to victory in an election marred by irregularities, violent protests and the arrest of his main opponent.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda arriving for a rally in Kampala on Tuesday. He is entering his third decade in office.

item.title: Russia Pulls Back From Cooperating With U.S. on Afghanistan
item.description: On an old Cold War battlefield where Russia fought a nearly decade-long war against United States-supplied fighters, Moscow has a new strategy: the cold shoulder.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: China Labels Protesters ‘Radical Separatists,’ and They Agree
item.description: Violence in the bustling Mong Kok district was the most startling sign yet of the rise of a confrontational local movement and the unlikely goal of Hong Kong independence.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If history decides we’re culpable for the violence, so be it,” said Edward Leung of the Hong Kong Indigenous group.

item.title: Fiji Declares a State of Natural Disaster in the Wake of a Fierce Cyclone
item.description: The storm, which had gusts up to 202 miles per hour, left villages destroyed and, reports say, at least one man dead in the east of the country.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Wreckage dotted the landscape on Sunday in Fiji after Cyclone Winston swept through, hitting hard in villages like this one, Ba.

item.title: India to Change Its Decades-Old Reliance on Female Sterilization
item.description: For decades, India has relied on female sterilization as its primary mode of contraception, funding about four million tubal ligations every year.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and CELIA W. DUGGER
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women lined up for examinations this month before sterilization surgery at a government hospital in Mahendragarh, India.

item.title: Former Prime Minister Wins Central African Republic’s Presidential Runoff
item.description: Faustin-Archange Touadéra inherits the enormous task of trying to restore order in a country where armed rebel groups still control much territory.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Serbian Hostages Killed in U.S. Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya
item.description: The deaths of two Serbian Embassy employees drew protests from Serbia and raised questions about the American intelligence that led to the strikes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY

item.title: Chinese Securities Regulator Is Out, but Little May Change
item.description: The dismissal of Xiao Gang is a gamble by President Xi Jinping that he can limit damage to the Communist Party from the struggling economy.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE, KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Xiao Gang, China’s top securities regulator, in 2012.

item.title: Divided Britain to Decide on Whether to Leave the E.U.
item.description: Britons will vote on June 23 on whether to stay in the European Union or to quit, Prime Minister David Cameron said on Saturday, a decision that could have momentous consequences for Britain and Europe.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron on Saturday in London. He said he would recommend a vote to stay in the 28-nation bloc.

item.title: After Paris Terror Attacks, France Struggles With Faith on the Job
item.description: France’s brand of secularism discourages, and sometimes bans, public religious expression, making workplaces prone to misunderstandings.
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bachir B. was a passenger screener at Orly airport, south of Paris, until he was fired. He had been cited for failing to adequately trim the thick beard that he wears in keeping with his Muslim beliefs.

item.title: Xiao Gang, China’s Top Securities Regulator, Ousted Over Market Tumult
item.description: Xiao Gang was chief of the China Securities Regulatory Commission. His replacement is Liu Shiyu, chairman of the Agricultural Bank of China.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Xiao Gang, who was replaced as chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, had been criticized for allowing a speculative bubble to form in the country’s stock market.

item.title: Umberto Eco, 84, Best-Selling Academic Who Navigated Two Worlds, Dies
item.description: Mr. Eco was an expert in the arcane field of semiotics whose seven works of fiction included the blockbuster medieval mystery “The Name of the Rose.”
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN KANDELL
item.media:credit: Roberto Serra/Iguana Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Umberto Eco in Bologna, Italy, last year. As a semiotician, Mr. Eco studied signs and symbols.

item.title: Reporters’ Group Calls for Turkey to Release Syrian Citizen-Journalist
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists said the journalist, Rami Jarrah, had been detained for unclear reasons after reporting in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: New Chinese Rules on Foreign Firms’ Online Content
item.description: New regulations will forbid any foreign company from publishing online content in China without the government’s consent.
item.category: State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (China)
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: A street scene in Beijing. Beginning March 10, foreign companies or foreign joint ventures operating in China will be restricted from disseminating a wide range of content online, including text, maps, games, animation, audio and video, without government approval.

item.title: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Limits of Strategy Against ISIS
item.description: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The aftermath of airstrikes on Friday in Sabratha, Libya. A Tunisian militant linked to attacks on tourists last year was targeted.

item.title: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 28 in Turkey’s capital, but Turkey’s leaders continued to blame a different Kurdish group, an ally of the United States.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Saudis Cut Off Funding for Military Aid to Lebanon
item.description: The move was a new step in a proxy war between countries who are on opposing sides in the wars in Yemen and Syria and competing for influence elsewhere across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: E.U. Deal Clears Path for British Referendum on Membership
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron agreed to a package of concessions that clear the way for him to call for a vote in Britain on whether to cut ties to the union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain arriving Friday for the second day of a European Union summit meeting in Brussels.
